docs.lead_paragraph: Matthew Jasper, 35, a poet from Farmington, N.H., had a brainstorm. After the birth of his second child, he said to his wife, ''Next time why don't we do this by ourselves?''

headline.main: When Giving Birth, Opting to Go It Alone

docs.abstract: Article on Beatrice and Matthew Jasper of Farmington, NH, and small, close-knit network of parents across US and abroad who are choosing unassisted childbirth; doctors and nurse-midwives oppose such births, citing serious complications that could result; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Matthew Jasper, 35, a poet from Farmington, N.H., had a brainstorm.     After the birth of his second child, he said to his wife, ''Next time why don't we do this by ourselves?''

docs.lead_paragraph: A college student who knew she was allergic to peanuts died after eating chili that had been thickened with peanut butter. Another college student died after eating cookies with a label that failed to mention peanuts as an ingredient because the manufacturer, not wanting to waste some leftover peanut cookie batter, added it to the batter for some other kind of cookie. A 15-year-old died on a Connecticut sidewalk after eating a piece of coffee cake that she thought was free of peanuts. A 14-year-old on a camping trip died after eating a sandwich made with a knife used to make a peanut butter and jelly sandwich.

headline.main: Dodging Peanuts: To Some, a Lifelong Challenge

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on lifelong challenges that both children and adults with potentially deadly peanut allergies face in determining what foods are safe to eat; describes symptoms and treatments; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Lori Rice was 10 when she started menstruating, and every month was an ordeal. ''I was having a lot of problems with my period -- cramping and heavy bleeding,'' said Lori, now 15. ''The pain was the worst. I missed a lot of school, and it got worse the longer I had my period.'' Her mother, Kathy Rice, took Lori to their family doctor, who prescribed heat, ibuprofen and calcium supplements. Heat gave Lori some relief, but it was not always a practical or sufficient solution.

headline.main: Beyond Birth Control: The Pill Tackles New Duties

docs.abstract: Article on trend toward treating adolescent and teenage girls suffering from menstrual cramping, heavy bleeding and other symptoms of dysmenorrhea with oral contraceptives; Dr Anne R Davis of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York is conducting first study of oral contraceptives in treatment of adolescent menstrual pain; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ASK Dan Quayle what he misses most about being vice president of the United States and he sounds a little like that midget from the old television program about that island. ''The plane! The plane!'' he says. Mr. Quayle, 10 years away from the comforts of Air Force Two, is a business traveler now -- ''another average Joe out there schlepping his bags, trying to make the next plane,'' he said in a recent interview.
docs.abstract: Former Vice Pres Dan Quayle, chairman of consulting firm Quayle & Associates, discusses rigors of traveling over 100,000 miles per year in airplanes and his work for finding help for deep-vein thrombosis, medical condition that occurs when blood clots form within a vein, usually in leg or pelvis; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MTV expects to close a deal this week with members of the family of the rock singer Ozzy Osbourne that will be the most expensive in the channel's history. Agents representing the Osbournes are expected in New York today to hammer out the remaining details of the new contract.

headline.main: Return Season of 'The Osbournes' Is Down to the Fine Print

docs.abstract: MTV expects to reach accord with members of rock singer Ozzy Osbourne's family that will be most expensive in channel's history for second season of reality program The Osbournes; show, with highest rating of any entertainment program on cable television this season, chronicles family's daily lives; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It's early tuesday, Jan. 20, 1998, in Wellsville, N.Y., and the sky is beginning to show streaks of light over in the east, behind Madison Hill. On Main Street, at Texas Hots, the waitresses are already pouring customers a second cup. Each morning, a half-dozen men huddle out front, waiting for the bank clock to strike 6 and the restaurant to unlock its doors so they can replant themselves on their rightful counter stools. By 6:45, Main Street is lined with pickup trucks, their exhaust white in the frosty air as they head over for first shift at Dresser-Rand, Wellsville's biggest employer, manufacturer of electric-generating steam turbines. Like most places, Wellsville has people with old money, new money, just enough money and no money. It's the old money -- oil money made in the nearby Pennsylvania oil fields at the turn of the last century -- that built those big homes along Main Street and gives Wellsville its special charm. As recently as 20 years ago, there were still ''oil widows'' in those elegant houses, but today it's the new money, mostly doctors, lawyers, business executives, who, for $200,000, own rambling Victorians that would go for a million or more in a New York City suburb.

headline.main: Did You Hear About Doc Ogden?

docs.abstract: Michael Winerip article on Dr Gary Ogden, general practitioner in Wellsville, NY, whose license was suspended for a year after death of baby that was delivered under his supervision and care at local hospital, event that brought into open his serious drinking problem; says drinking was well known among townspeople and was in good part due to pressures arising from Ogden's efforts to be all things to his town and patients; says Ogden, now in Alcoholics Anonymous and subject to random alcohol monitoring, no longer practices medicine but is county health director, by all accounts doing first-rate job; describes deep impact of baby's death and Ogden's suspension on town and all involved; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: I was recently in France with my wife, who forgot her oral contraceptives. I easily persuaded a pharmacist to supply her, and at the equivalent of $1.50 for a brand that costs $35 here. We bought a year's supply. Who acted unethically? Me, a physician not licensed in France? The pharmacist, who handed out drugs without a prescription? My wife, who takes them? The drug company, which excessively inflates its prices in America? Franz H. Messerli, M.D., New Orleans The pharmacist acted best. He may have broken the law by providing contraceptives without a prescription, but he showed courage and humanity in helping a traveler. In his defense, he provided them to a woman who had used them for years, and he was guided by a doctor, albeit an out-of-towner not licensed in France. Had he refused, he might have placed your wife at risk of an unwanted pregnancy with potentially unpleasant consequences. Finally, he doled out birth-control pills, not morphine.

headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 5-5-02: THE ETHICIST

docs.abstract: Randy Cohen The Ethicist column answers two questions related to medicine, one from doctor who got prescription for birth control pills for his wife while traveling in France and bought year's supply of them because they were much cheaper there, and one from cellphone user whose voice mail sometimes includes messages from patients of doctor with similar telephone number; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: SACCONE'S PIZZERIA in New Rochelle is nothing remarkable from the outside; just a small corner shack on Washington Avenue with too-bright blue painting, and missing O's on both sides of its red plastic sign. But inside, with rich marinara sauce simmering in the back, pizza crisping in the oven, Saccone's is a second kitchen to the neighborhood. Its owners, Maria and Pasquale Miele, are veritable surrogate parents. Seven days a week, the Mieles serve up staples native to their hometown outside Naples: pasta e fagioli soup, spicy penna al'arrabiata and a delectable assortment of pizza, from artichoke to pepperoni. They listen to tales (oh, do they listen), of lost loves, of illness, of engagements and pregnancy cravings. For whatever ails, there is always a slice, some hot zeppoles or freshly baked garlic knots, just to help things along.
docs.abstract: Gabrielle Glaser County Lines column on Saccone's Pizzeria in New Rochelle, NY, owned and operated by Maria and Pasquale Miele and their children, where sense of family and neighborhood prevails; drawing (M)

byline.original: By James Barron with Glenn Collins

docs.lead_paragraph: Ten years after riots burned through the inner city here, Los Angeles is marking the occasion with a cascade of speeches, and to a remarkable degree, the talk is rosy. Community leaders have congratulated themselves for restoring the cityscape with dozens of new shopping complexes, and for conducting multiethnic forums.

headline.main: Los Angeles Inner City Beset By Chronic Health Problems

docs.abstract: South Central Los Angeles, blighted community that has made economic strides since rioting of 1992, still has some of most widespread and chronic health problems in Los Angeles County, including crippling levels of diabetes, lung cancer, asthma, obesity and heart disease; situation is aggravated by fact that largely Latino immigrant population has highest number of uninsured people in county; budget problems are forcing county health department to reduce its budget sharply and possibly lay off staff members (M)
